title-group.article-title: Visual analysis of research hot topics and trends of clinical decision support system based on CiteSpace

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/01hv94n30grid.412277.50000 0004 1760 6738Department of general surgery, Ruijin Hospital, Shanghai Jiaotong University School of Medicine, Shanghai, 200020 China

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Clinical decision support system (CDSS) mainly refers to a computer application system that uses relevant and systematic clinical knowledge and patients’ basic information, as well as medical information, to strengthen medical-related decisions/actions and improve medical quality and medical service level.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To analyze research status, hot topics and developmental trends, and to provide references for future research in this field.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: CiteSpace was used to conduct scientific measurement and visualization analysis of relevant literature from 1969 to 2023 in the Web of Science core collection database.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 2473 documents were included, and the number of publications increased exponentially (y = 1.3073e0.1636x), and the attention to this field has gradually increased. The research frontier trends mainly focus on the combination of CDSS and artificial intelligence, as well as the development and exploration of deep learning models for different application environments. With the continuous development of science and technology, the prospect of combining artificial intelligence with CDSS is very promising.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study reveals an in-depth and comprehensive perspective for CDSS study, and provides researchers with valuable information on the current status, hot topics, and cutting-edge trends in this field.

custom-meta.meta-value: © Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Computerized clinical decision support systems (CDSS) represent a paradigm shift in today’s healthcare field [1], and as CDSS is gradually improved, it has been gradually applied to different fields [2]. In recent years, scholars have studied CDSS for antibiotic prescriptions [3], prediction of cancer [4], the impact of workload, work complexity, and repeated alarms on alarm fatigue [5], pharmacological risk assessment [6], development and effectiveness of pressure ulcer prevention and care [7]. Although some progress has been made, there is a lack of macro and comprehensive sorting and summarization. Based on this, the author made a relatively detailed and comprehensive summarization of the literature in the field of CDSS, revealing the development status, hot topics, and cutting-edge trends in this field.

CiteSpace visualization was developed by Professor Chaomei Chen of Drexel University (USA). The software can visually identify the potential patterns within literature [8]. By interpreting network graph information, scholars can quickly and accurately grasp the current status, hot topics, and research trends in related fields [9]. Based on a database with great international influence, this study systematically and comprehensively reveals the research progress and characteristics in this field from multiple perspectives such as countries, institutions, authors, journals, keywords, and co-citations, aiming to contribute to its development and provide theoretical reference for other scholars.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: The study uses the Web of Science Core Collection (WOSCC) as the source database, with a publication deadline of May 26, 2023. Based on search criteria TS = (“Clinical Decision Support System”) OR TS = (“clinic *” AND “Decision Support System”) OR TS = (“clinic *” AND “Decision Support” AND “System”), a total of 2704 documents were retrieved. After excluding documents with document types other than “Article” and “Review”, 2510 documents remained. Refinement of language to English resulted in 2473 documents. The contents were downloaded with full record and all references in plain text format, and named as download_N (N is a natural number). After being imported into the CiteSpace software to remove duplicates, 2473 valid documents were obtained.

sec.title: Analysis tools
sec.p: Microsoft Excel was used to draw a trend chart of the annual publication volume for 2473 documents.

CiteSpace 5.7.R1 was used to perform visual analysis on countries/regions, institutions, authors, keywords, and co-citations of documents. Software parameter settings: time span: 1969–2023; timeslice = 5 years; node type was country, institution, author, keyword, or citation reference respectively; node threshold mainly used g-index (K = 10, 15, 25); pruning mainly used Pathfinder or MST algorithm based on data features, with pruning sliced networks was checked at the same time. In the country/region, institution, and author maps, the size of the node is proportional to the number of publications. The larger the node, the greater the number of publications. The connecting line indicates a cooperative relationship. In the keyword map, the size of the node is proportional to the frequency. The larger the node, the higher the number of keyword appearances. The connecting line indicates a co-occurrence relationship. In the literature co-citation map, the size of the node is proportional to the number of co-citations. The larger the node, the more co-citations. The connecting line indicates a co-citation relationship. The purple edge of the node in the map indicates that the centrality is ≥ 0.1. High centrality indicates a turning point in the field. The keyword cluster map is obtained by clustering the keywords based on the co-occurrence of keywords using the LLR algorithm and marking them with “K”. The cluster information table is explored using the “Cluster Export” function. The modules divided in the cluster map are marked with #, and the structure and clarity of the cluster are mainly determined by two indicators: the modularity value (referred to as Q value) and the average silhouette value (referred to as S value). The larger the Q value, the better the network clustering. The range of Q is {0,1}. Q >0.3 means that the clustering network structure is significant. S measures the homogeneity of the clustering graph. S ≥ 0.5 means the clustering result can be considered reasonable [10].

sec.title: Annual publication analysis
sec.p:
According to Fig. 1, the number of documents in the field of CDSS shows an overall rising trend. The number of documents fluctuates exponentially with the year (y = 1.3073e0.1636x). Research in this field can be traced back to the 1960s. During the period from 1969 to 2004, there were few publications, and it was in the early stages of development. The annual number of publications was less than 20, and the overall publication rate during this period was about 3.03 per year. The number of published articles showed a fluctuating rising trend from 2005 to 2018, with the publication rate being approximately 92.79 per year, an increase of 552%. The number of published articles showed a rapid rising trend from 2019 to 2022, with the publication rate reaching 246.00 per year and peaked in 2022, during which the attention to this field increased significantly. Since the search date is limited to 26 May, 2023, the statistics on the literature in 2023 are incomplete. However, based on the annual trend and fitting curve, it can be predicted that the number of publications in this field will continue to grow.Fig. 1
Trends in the number of publications during 1969–2023

sec.title: Analysis of National distribution
sec.p:
The national cooperation map (Fig. 2) was generated using CiteSpace software, with N = 482 and E = 1184, i.e., a total of 482 nodes and 1184 connecting lines. Table 1 lists the information of the top 10 countries in terms of output. According to the chart, the countries cooperate closely with each other, among which the USA has the largest output of literature (750 articles), accounting for approximately30.33% of the total literature. England (185 articles), accounting for approximately7.48%, ranked second, and CHINA (158 articles), accounting for about 6.39%, ranked third. The Netherlands, South Korea, Spain, Canada, Germany, India, and Italy are also relatively high-yield countries. The country with the highest centrality is the USA (0.48), followed by Canada (0.19) and England (0.18), indicating that the international recognition of the research results of these three countries in this field is high, and their impact is relatively significant.Fig. 2
National cooperation networkTable 1

sec.title: Institutional analysis
sec.p:
An institutional collaboration network (Fig. 3) was generated by CiteSpace, which contains 205 nodes and 517 connecting lines. A node in the graph corresponds to an institution, and a connecting line indicates a collaborative relationship between institutions. Table 2 lists the information of the 10 institutions with the highest number of publications.Fig. 3
Institutional cooperation diagramTable 2
Information of high-yield institutions

According to the graph, institutions in the field of CDSS have formed a relatively close cooperative relationship. According to the table, the Mayo Clin in the United States has the most papers (39), accounting for 1.58%. Brigham & Womens Hosp and Harvard Med Sch both published 35 papers, ranking second and third. The institutions with greater centrality are Columbia Univ (0.13) and Brigham & Womens Hosp (0.12). High-yield institutions and high-impact institutions are mostly concentrated in the United States.

sec.title: Author analysis
sec.p:
The author cooperation network (Fig. 4) contains a total of 284 nodes and 433 connecting lines. In the graph, a node corresponds to an author. The larger the node, the greater the number of articles the corresponding author has published. The lines indicate that there is a cooperative relationship between the authors.Fig. 4
Author collaboration network

Table 3 lists the top 10 authors in terms of publication number. According to the chart, the authors have formed a close cooperative relationship. Among them, Stephen M. Downs is the author with the highest number of articles (22) in this field. Shaker Elsappagh has published 18 articles, ranking second. Brigitte Seroussi has published 14 articles, ranking third, followed by Sungyoung Lee (13 articles), Aaron E. Carroll (12 articles), Jens Kaltschmidt (12 articles), Ameen Abuhanna (12 articles), etc. From the perspective of publication time, the first publication of high-yield authors are mostly concentrated in 2009.Table 3

sec.title: Journal analysis
sec.p:
Table 4 lists the top 10 journals in terms of the number of articles published in this field. According to the table, the journal with the most articles published in the field of CDSS is Studies in Health Technology and Informatics (125 articles), accounting for approximately 5.05% of the total literature. This journal is relatively influential in the field of medical informatics. The second is Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association (68 articles), with an impact factor of 7.942 in 2022 and a journal classification of Q1. Followed by BMC Medical Informatics and Decision Making (66 articles), with an impact factor of 3.298 and a journal classification of Q3; International Journal of Medical Informatics (57 articles), with an impact factor of 4.730 and a journal classification of Q1. The journals with the largest impact factors are Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association (7.942) and Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine (7.027). Among the top ten journals, Q1 accounts for 5 out of 10, indicating that the quality of articles in this field is high and the research value is high as well.Table 4
Journal information (top ten)

sec.title: Analysis of research hot topics and trends
sec.p: The hot topics and trends in the field of CDSS are mainly explored through keyword co-occurrence, clustering, document co-citation and mutation. Keywords are a high-level summary of the core ideas of an article. In CiteSpace, keywords can be explored based on keyword co-occurrence relationships [11]. Document co-citation mainly refers to the connection formed by two documents being cited by the citing document at the same time. It is a dynamically changing relationship. In CiteSpace, the dynamic relationship of document co-citation can be displayed [12]. Using quantitative visualization tools to extract and explore co-citation document information and analyze keyword co-occurrence and clustering can successfully identify the development trends and hot topics in this field.

sec.title: Keyword analysis
sec.p:
The keyword co-occurrence map (Fig. 5) has 292 nodes and 327 connecting lines. The nodes in the map represent keywords, and connecting lines represent co-occurrence relationships. The top 10 keywords in terms of frequency and centrality are shown in Table 5. The most frequent keyword in the map is CDSS (1051 times), and the corresponding node is the largest. The keyword care (246 times) is ranked second. The next keywords are “management”, “system”, “diagnosis”, “impact”, “machine learning”, “implementation”, “guideline”, and “classification”. The centrality of the top ten keywords is ≥ 0.2, among which the keywords “system (0.57)”, “information (0.39)”, “improve (0.31)”, “heart disease (0.31)”, and “medication error (0.27)” are in the top five.Fig. 5
Keyword co-occurrence mapTable 5

Keyword clustering was obtained using CiteSpace (Fig. 6), with a Q value of 0.8349 and an S value of 0.7857. The clustering results were reasonable and significant as a whole, and were scientifically reliable. There are 14 keyword clusters #0-#13 in the figure, namely “#0using machine learning, #1 clinical decision support system, # 2behavioral economics, #3 using pupillometry, #4 patient outcome, #5 dynamic decision model, #6 electronic asthma management system, #7 repurposing clinical decision support system data, #8 computerized physician order entry, #9 antibiotic treatment, #10 pediatric obesity, #11 clinical condition, #12 infectious-disease outbreak, and #13 early cancer detection”. The cluster number is sorted mainly according to the cluster size, that is, the smaller the number, the more keywords the cluster contains.Fig. 6
Keyword clustering network

Table 6 summarizes the specific information of each cluster. The results show that the indicators of each cluster are within a reasonable range, indicating that the individual clusters are good with high module homogeneity and scientific reliability. Specifically, cluster #0 contains 30 keywords with the top 5 are using machine learning, knowledge acquisition, occupational health, ethical consideration, and involving periodic workers health assessment; cluster #1 contains 30 keywords with the top 5 are clinical decision support system, Bayesian program, rheumatological diagnoses, computer-assisted diagnosis, and bi-level belief rule; cluster #2 contains 29 keywords with the top 5 are behavioral economics, rural India, technology-enabled mental health services delivery model, systematic medical appraisal referral, and mental health project; cluster #3 contains 27 keywords with the top 5 are using pupillometry, pediatric age, automatic detection, genetic diseases, and to-end deep learning framework; cluster #4 contains 27 keywords with the top 5 are patient outcome, blood pressure, chronic kidney disease stage, general practice, and digital allergology; cluster #5 contains 27 keywords with the top 5 are dynamic decision model, applying human factors principle, potential new approaches, mapping patient data, and clinical algorithm; cluster #6 contains 25 keywords with the top 5 are electronic asthma management system, guides checklist evaluation, of-care computerized clinical decision support system, system uptake analysis, and large healthcare system; cluster #7 contains 22 keywords with the top 5 are repurposing CDSS data, dosing error, clinician-level quality, cognitive support, and clinical workflow; cluster #8 contains 21 keywords with the top 5 are computerized physician order entry, nursing care plan, alert fatigue, machine learning approach, and medication-related clinical decision support system; cluster #9 contains 20 keywords with the top 5 are antibiotic treatment, explainable decision support, formal ontology, using artificial intelligence, and lateral cephalometric radiograph; cluster #10 contains 18 keywords with the top 5 are pediatric obesity, documentation-based decision support, chronic disease management, computerized chronic disease management system, and safety net clinics; cluster #11 contains 18 keywords with the top 5 are prescribing safety, long-term follow-up evaluation, pragmatic randomized trial, positive predictive value, and clinical rule; cluster #12 contains 18 keywords with the top 5 are infectious-disease outbreak, emergency response, large-scale dispensing, mass dispensing, and infectious disease outbreak; cluster #13 contains 18 keywords with the top 5 are early cancer detection, drug-related problem, clinical pharmacist, physicians responses, and intensive care unit-comparison.Table 6

sec.title: Co-citation analysis of literature
sec.p:
Figure 7 is obtained by running with “Cited Reference” as the node and Look Back Year = 8 years, that is, the backtracking period is 8 years. The map has a total of 218 nodes and 242 connecting lines. Tables 7 and 8 list the co-citation count and the top 5 centrality literature’s information. “Effects of Computerized Clinical Decision Support Systems on Practitioner Performance and Patient Outcomes-A Systematic Review” is the most co-cited article in the field of CDSS, with a total citation count of 100. It was published by Garg AX, Adhikari NKJ et al. in the top international journal JAMA-Journal of the American Medical Association in 2005 [IF (2022)= 157.335, Q1]. The article pointed out that computerized CDSS improved clinicians’ performance, but the impact on patient prognosis has not been fully studied, and even if it has been studied, the results are inconsistent [13]. “Overriding of Drug Safety Alerts in Computerized Physician Order Entry” is the article with the highest centrality (0.84). It was published by Van der Sijs H, Aarts J et al. in the Journal of The American Medical Informatics Association [IF (2022) = 7.942, Q1] in 2006. The article studied drug safety alerts in computerized physician order entry (CPOE) systems and pointed out the efforts to improve patient safety by increasing the correct handling of drug safety alerts should focus on error-generating conditions in software and organizations. In addition, research on the role of cognitive processes in overcoming drug safety alerts is still lacking [14].Fig. 7
Co-citation network of documentsTable 7

sec.title: Research trend analysis
sec.p:
The results of keyword mutation (Fig. 8) are obtained by using the Burstness function of CiteSpace. In the process, the minimum duration is set to 2 years. In the graph, “Begin” indicates the start time of the mutation, “End” indicates the end time of the mutation, and the red part indicates the mutation time span.Fig. 8
Keyword mutation

From the top 10 mutation keyword graphs, it can be seen that “computer” has mutated since 1993 and continued to 2009, with a mutation intensity of 12.7919, which is the longest mutation time, indicating that computer research is of great significance to the development of this field. The mutation intensity of “artificial intelligence” is the largest, which is 19.7284, followed by “machine learning” with a mutation intensity of 19.3178, ranking second, and “performance” with a mutation intensity of 19.0636, ranking third. The mutation times of “machine learning”, “deep learning” and “artificial intelligence” are 2020–2023, 2020–2023, and 2021–2023, respectively, and all continue to the present. They are current research hot topics and future research trends.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The data of in this article comes from the relevant literature in CDSS field from 1969 to 2023 in the WOS database. The CiteSpace visualization software is used to display the data from multiple aspects, including country, institution, author, journal, keyword, and total citation. The relevant literature is scientifically and comprehensively sorted out and explored to reveal the research status, hot topics and trends in this field.

The number of publications in this field increases exponentially (y = 1.3073e0.1636x), with an average annual publication of about 45.0 articles, and the overall attention is gradually increasing too. Among them, the USA has the largest output of documents, accounting for about 30.33% of the total documents, and countries such as England, CHINA, and the Netherlands are also relatively high-yielding countries. The cooperation network between countries is closely connected, and the USA, Canada, and England are countries with greater influence.

The institutions that publish papers are closely connected and have formed a strong cooperative relationship. High-yielding institutions and high-impact institutions are mostly concentrated in the United States. Among them, Mayo Clin is the most productive institution, with an output accounting for about 1.58% of the total literature. Columbia Univ and Brigham & Womens Hosp have a high degree of institutional centrality and are institutions with great influence in this field. The research results of the above institutions are of great significance to the development of this field.

Good cooperative relationship has been formed between the authors in this field. Among them, STEPHEN M DOWNS is the most productive author, accounting for about 0.89% of the total literature. His research mainly focuses on long-term acceptability evaluation and investigation of pediatric CDSS users [15], the prevalence of pain in pediatric primary care and its relationship with demographics, body mass index and examination results [16], computer automated decision support system to improve physician diagnosis of childhood asthma [17], the effectiveness of computer automation in the diagnosis and treatment of type 2 diabetes in children [18].

From the perspective of journals, Q1 accounts for 5 out of 10 of the top ten journals, and the quality of the literature is high, meaning they all have important research value. Among them, the journal with the largest number of articles is Studies in Health Technology and Informatics, accounting for about 5.05% of the total literature. This journal has great influence in medical informatics. The journals with the largest impact factors are Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association [IF (2022) = 7.942] and Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine [IF (2022) = 7.027].

Keywords with high research frequency in the field of CDSS are clinical decision support system, care, management, system, diagnosis, impact, machine learning, implementation, guideline, classification, etc. In terms of centrality, the keywords system, information, improve, heart disease, and medicine error are ranked in the top five, which are the most influential research. Among them, the healthy elderly population is an important subject of clinical trials, and the age of onset is a key factor in determining the obvious characteristics of patients with cognitive dysfunction, such as pathological burden and structural changes [19]. Clustering results are scientifically reasonable and reliable, and are mainly divided into #0 using machine learning, #1 clinical decision support system, #2 behavioral economics, #3 using pupillometry, #4 patient outcome, #5 dynamic decision model, #6 electronic asthma management system, #7 repurposing clinical decision support system data, #8 computerized physician order entry, #9antibiotic treatment, #10 pediatric obesity, #11 clinical condition, #12 infectious-disease outbreak, and #13 early cancer detection. From the above, it can be seen that disease diagnosis and prediction, information management, machine learning, system improvement and implementation, and impact based on CDSS are the main research hot topics. Among them, CDSS is of great significance in the diagnosis and prediction of diseases, and so far, it mainly involves the risk prediction of heart failure, breast cancer, cardiac chest pain, childhood obesity, venous thromboembolic disease, and prevention of glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis [20–25]. Management mainly involves primary care, drug safety, and electronic health records [26–28]. In addition, there are many studies on how to improve the implementation of CDSS and the impact of the system on clinical practice.

High co-cited and high centrality documents are all published in journals with relatively high international influence and have high academic reference value. The contents of high co-citation documents mainly involve the impact of CDSS on clinician performance and patient prognosis [11], research progress of CDSS, benefits, risks and success strategies of CDSS, improvement of CDSS and clinical practice, and characteristics of effective computerized CDSS [29–32]. The contents of high centrality documents mainly involve drug safety alerts in computerized CPOE systems [12], the impact of electronic prescriptions on medication errors and adverse drug events, coverage fatigue of drug-related clinical decision support alerts for outpatients, CPOE with clinical decision support (CDS), and the number and types of drug safety alerts in a large university medical center in the Netherlands [33–36].

Keyword “computer” has the longest mutation time, and “artificial intelligence” has the largest mutation intensity, which is 19.7284. The mutation time of “machine learning”, “deep learning” and “artificial intelligence” is 2020–2023, 2020–2023 and 2021–2023, respectively, all of which have continued up to today, and are the current research hot topics and future research trends. CDSS enables users to make decisions based on clinical data from electronic medical records, thereby promoting personalized precision treatment. Scholar Kim JK used machine learning to design a pathological staging and biochemical recurrence prediction method for prostate cancer process based on digital twins [37]. Cui SG established a machine learning prediction model and application system for personalized analysis of the risk of hemorrhagic complications in patients receiving intravenous thrombolysis [38]. Ragab M used ultrasound images to develop a CDSS for breast cancer diagnosis and classification with integrated deep learning support [39]. Foersch S used digital pathology and deep learning models as CDSS to diagnose and predict the prognosis of soft tissue sarcoma [40]. Diaz−Ramon JL analyzed simple serological and histopathological biomarkers through artificial intelligence algorithms to accurately predict the risk of metastasis and disease−free interval of melanoma patients [41]. This low−cost melanoma CDSS is an effective tool to help clinicians manage melanoma patients. Tsopra R’s research suggested there was an urgent need for digital health programs to accelerate the application of artificial intelligence and clinical decision support systems (AI−CDSS) in clinical settings [42]. Taken together, it can be seen that with the advancement of science and technology,, as well as the development and exploration of deep learning models for different application environments will be the trend of future research. This study explored the current status, research hot topics and cutting-edge trends in the field of CDSS from 1969 to 2023, and made important summaries. CDSS plays an important role in the development of the world’s medical and health fields. Different countries, institutions and scholars should continue to maintain good cooperative relations to jointly promote the development of this field. Research hot topics are mainly involved in the disease diagnosis and prediction, information management, machine learning, system improvement and implementation, and impact of CDSS. Future research trends are mainly reflected in the combination of CDSS and artificial intelligence, as well as the development and exploration of deep learning models for different application environments. Especially with the continuous development of science and technology, the prospect of combining artificial intelligence with CDSS will be very promising.

However, this study also has some shortcomings. Despite the strengths of this study, several limitations should be acknowledged. First, the literature search was conducted up to May 26, 2023, with the analysis time window defined as 1969–2023. While this ensures data consistency across all analyses, it may underrepresent the most recent developments, as incorporating new literature would require reanalysis and extensive revision of visualizations, which is beyond the scope of the current review cycle. Second, the study adopts a metadata-driven bibliometric approach based on titles, keywords, and citations, without full-text content analysis. This enables the identification of macro-level trends and influential studies but may overlook nuanced findings and methodologies. Future research could integrate content-based text mining or natural language processing for deeper insights. Third, the data were exclusively sourced from the Web of Science Core Collection. Although it is a widely recognized and authoritative database, the exclusion of sources such as Scopus, PubMed, or IEEE Xplore may affect the comprehensiveness of the dataset. In addition, the visualization figures, while generated at the highest resolution allowed by CiteSpace, may appear dense or complex. Nonetheless, efforts have been made to optimize layout and color contrast for improved readability. Lastly, all previously noted typographical and formatting errors, including superscript issues in the Discussion section, have been carefully corrected to enhance clarity and presentation.
